comments.commentBody:
these are 2 questions that bother me about Bernie. Is there any way to get an answer?
1. In the case of free tuition what will control the money? If it is the states what is to prevent states from controlling the class material? If the federal government how will that be addressed?
2. It seems to me that getting free health care and free tuition will be difficult to get thru congress. What are you willing to give in order to get the needed votes?

Mary Ann – there are 34 seats up for election in November; 24 are Republicans running for reelection. Democrats need to gain 5 of those seats.
Illinois has a good shot at picking up a Dem seat with Tammy Duckworth.
(btw, our current Repub Sen isn't one of the bad guys, but he's a Repub, so we've gotta vote him out.) This appears to be doable.
GOTV!

Chris- the other economically advanced countries do not attempt to act as the world's policeman, either.  If we finally relinquish that role we could probably cut our military expenditures by at least a half, and what the resulting billions could pay for in the civilian sector would boggle the mind! And it wouldn't hurt to return to the tax structure of the Eisenhower years, where the highest marginal rate was about 90%.  Would any of this get past congress? Of course not.  The Rs have an unbreakable gerrymandered stranglehold on the House. Perhaps we should petition the UN to oversee our elections.  There seems to be no other way out of this intractable situation.

trk, he is not saying "free" health care.  He is saying we could, and should, have the same kind of health care that most Western nations enjoy.  Medicare is not free.  It's not very expensive, but not free.  If it's open to all, it will be much cheaper for those not yet in retirement, but not free.  And, yes, taxes will have to be raised.  There's no free lunch.  But it especially has to be raised for those who have not been paying their fair share.  Nothing is perfect, but with single payer or Medicare for all, we would be a helluva lot better off than we are now.

these are 2 questions that bother me about Bernie. Is there any way to get an answer?
1. In the case of free tuition what will control the money? If it is the states what is to prevent states from controlling the class material? If the federal government how will that be addressed?
2. It seems to me that getting free health care and free tuition will be difficult to get thru congress. What are you willing to give in order to get the needed votes?
But as Blow explains, current data does not show this, so why is it a relevant hypothesis?

What data? Surely not polling data since it is so unreliable. Btw if a committed democrat, start learning  to say President Trump. If it makes your blood pressure rise, vote for the Democrat, no matter who is nominated.

In case of free tuition, it wasn't that long ago (or at least, it doesn't seem that way to me) that virtually free tuition was available in California - the California State Universities, and the great University of California system were affordable to someone working at minimum wage (me) - the numbers I recall (this was in the 70's) are about $90/semester for Cal State, and $210/quarter for UCLA. Somehow that was doable then, paid by state taxes. Why is it impossible now?

As far as paying for health care, our current system, dominated by for profit insurers, is more expensive - not less - than the health care system of all other first world countries who provide universal health care.

As far as the "needed votes," as long as we have a Tea party/Republican dominated Congress, it is unlikely that these, or anything, will get done by ANY Democratic president. But we can at least move the conversation to the left so the public has some sense of what is at stake that actually impacts them.

It is so refreshing to see adults disagree over policy without resorting to personal insults, completely generic feel good statements, or spew right wing hate.

We can only hope as a country that one of the two who debated tonight will be our next commander-in-chief.

One is six years older than Reagan was, never got a steady paycheck until elected at age 40, after 25 years in WashDC has led only one law's making and has a reputation of being "cranky."

The other has 100 FBI agents going through her records and more than 60% of Americans called her "dishonest" after 35 years in "public service."

We are the only "hope" in this equation.

Were you actually watching the debate? My 9 year old son commented how 'unbelievably rude' the candidates were - shouting each other down, ignoring the moderators, lying through her teeth.  No better than Trump/Rubio.  There all abominations - except ... well, no exceptions.
We all know who that one is too.
I fail to see the optimism you attribute to Bernie Sanders.
Arno, the allegiance is in the nearly double popular vote count.

It's Bernie's choice if he wants to support the eventual (fixed) Democratic ticket. But I will vote for Dr. Jill Stein, a woman!, if Bernie is not the Dem nominee. I don't owe the Dems my vote and they don't own it.
I'd say that's your fault, not Sanders'.

As someone who voted for Obama twice but now supports Trump, I'm not sure who would be easier to beat. Once he turns his attention to it, Trump can easily define them.

Hillary would be the lying Wall St. puppet who should get indicted. Sanders would be the socialist who will raise everyone's taxes to be like Europe (a failing continent).

Laurette, you post this all the time, emphasizing quality of life where you live, but you live in Greece, and your "quality of life" has left that country insolvent. Do you really suggest the U.S. follow that lead?
Sorry, makes sense to me.
When do you turn 8, Laurette?

Hillary Clinton did very poorly in this debate. She could not answer a question straight and was very general in her prescription for what this country needs.
Her message lacked conviction and enthusiasm.

Bernie Sanders was consistent and honest. He did not back down from his record, dove deeper into the details, and was confident.
Sanders provided details?  What channel were you watching?  I saw a different debate. I thought there was only one last night...

The first thing that jumps into my head is, would this be an effective treatment for autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, lupus, and etc. I am sure the people who developed the desensitization technique have already thought about this; and if I was a science reporter, it would have been among the very first questions I would have asked.
I have a family member who was diagnosed with Lupus and thought of the same exact question.

The procedure they are talking about is called plasmapheresis. This procedure has been used for decades now for many different conditions, some autoimmune diseases included. I am a physician who performs plasmapheresis, and we have already used this for desensitization for heart transplants. I think it's great that its use can be expanded to kidney transplant, but there also needs to be more awareness in the medical community about all of the other indications and potential benefits of plasmapheresis.

The procedure they are referring to that removes the antibodies is called plasmapheresis.  Plasmapheresis has been used for decades now to treat a wide variety of conditions, some autoimmune diseases among them.  I am a physician who works in a plasmapheresis service, and we have used it for desensitization for potential heart transplant patients.  It is also often used to treat certain types of organ transplant rejection after transplant.  I think it's great that we can expand the use of plasmapheresis to kidney transplant desensitization.  We also need to do our best to make the medical community more aware of the many uses and benefits of plasmapheresis.

Bernie has the edge in 2 critical ways. This campaign is all about inspiring voters about a better future. Bernie does that much better than Hillary. But more importantly, Bernie is defining what it means to be a progressive in 2016 America, and all Hillary can do is follow and copy.
I'd love to know what Cubans would say, wouldn't you? A hint: they left in droves.

And that is precisely the problem with Hillary; she is telling us what she will 'TRY" to do.

Never will she commit, since she must first check with the individuals who own her.
Mel, how about this: Hillary knows what she wants to do, and she hopes she will be able to shepherd those programs through. Bernie says it will happen...fairytales.

A decent, honest person against a greedy dishonest one. How are the Clintons still on the stage after all we've seen of them?

I don't agree with all Sanders says on the economic front, but he says what he believes and has for his entire career. Clinton will say anything to anyone for a vote. The country needs to restore decency and integrity to the office of the president. Sanders is the only one running who can do that.
Mel, why don't you to something Bernie does not do: state specifically what Secretary Clinton has done to earn your mistrust.
I would find the accusations and innuendo against the Clintons more credible if they had a source other than the Republican Party.
How's Myra?

Passionate debate and strong performances by both candidates.

That said, Senator Sanders shone. His authenticity and strong advocacy for ordinary Americans far outstrip Secretary Clinton's pallid centralism.

It was clear in this debate that Secretary Clinton's policies are pale copies of Senator Sanders'. If halfway measures appeal, Secretary Clinton is your candidate. If you want the real deal, support Senator Sanders.

Eileen, maybe living in the UK has distorted your view. The Bernie Bros are wholly a creation of Hillary's campaign. When an article bashing them came out there were two examples: One was a hillary supporter, the other was  a Republican. She did it to Obama, to, calling them Obama boys. She can spin any threat into sexism.

He's accomplished quite a lot.   He sponsored an amendment providing $100 million in additional funding to community health centers.  He did his part to help prevent child labor by passing an amendment which stopped the US from appropriating funds for the importation of goods made by the hands of minors. He sponsored (and helped to pass) an amendment which increased low-income home energy assistance and a related weatherization assistance program by $22 million, which helped heat the homes of poor households.  The list goes on and on (google is your friend; feel free to learn more.)  I'd say that's more than talk.
He was a conscientious objector, he was not prescient. He will always vote against war, which may play havoc with existing treaties.

Bernie is an elderly idealist, who believes his own mantra. It will take him two long years, as it did Obama, to learn what he can and can't do – in particular that he can't tear up these trade agreements. As evidence, look how long it took him to understand what was really going on at the VA – as reported recently by The Times: http://tinyurl.com/j4mzv9e .

By then he'll be 78, an age when we all slow down. Will he have the energy to regroup and start all over again with a new plan, even if he remains in good health? We can't afford another presidential learning curve.

Whether it's Bernie or Hillary in the Oval Office, not much big legislation will likely pass the Republican Congress. Most of the action will be in the foreign policy arena. Can anyone with a straight face claim that Bernie is ready for the mad provocations of Vlad Putin or Ali Khamenei?

Hillary may have problems of authenticity and trustworthiness. Bernie, who believes his own false promises, has a huge problem of credibility. Older voters have seen this movie before, and simply don't believe him. Myself, I find his detachment from reality scary. I'll take Hillary.

I learned from reading David McCullough's book "Truman" many years ago and everything I've read, seen or heard ever since confirms that the Presidency is essentially a job of decision making. Day in, day out, tons of decisions have to be made.

The Obama presidency confirms this: judgment, the ability to make good decisions is more important than experience. Obama had much of the former and almost none of the latter - though in truth his biggest mistake appears to be that he thought Congress would be reasonable in their dealings with him.

So, I am asking you, or Prof. Krugman, or any other Hillary supporter to please, please, please, provide for us all a list of good decisions that Hillary has made.

We all know about the ton of bad decisions she has made: from the decision to give overly high paid speeches to the Banksters/BigMoney on the eve of running for President, to voting for the war, to backing trade agreements, to backing deregulation, to backing 3 strikes & your out (which packed America's prisons to levels higher than any other nation), to welfare reform, etc..

Whereas Bernie has a track record of making decisions on the right side history going back to the 1960s civil rights era.

We are voting for decision maker in chief. She couldn't turn down bankster money out of foresight for something happening only a year & a half away in time? Hillary lost in 2008 because she was all tactics & no strategy. So I have no faith in her decision making ability. Help me out.

Consider this, at the time for voting for the Iraq war the American people didn't yet know our Republican administration was lying did they? So if you agree that was the case and regardless of how our media and CIA failed us, was it bad judgement to vote for the war, if an immediate threat were to exist? Forgive me, but in many peoples opinion that was bad judgement, but only in reflection, a lucky decision for him. Second, as a private citizen, your saying Hillary shouldn't make money because of who it came from or because you felt she made to much? And on the crime bill from decades ago, you blame her for the  levels of incarceration. Try this, where were all of the Bernie fans before he up and decides he wants to be President? why has there been no massive increase in voting for the revolution? where were they in 2010, in 2012, in 2014 when Obama needed liberals the most to vote? They were sitting on their backsides complaining about how bad things were while they didn't bother voting. So the Congress flipped Republican and we get no active governance at all. So Hillary was out making a fortune speaking so she would have a lot of money to run for office, well that's just awful right? How about the fight for campaign finance reform that will help to end the influence of the very few - where have all the Bernie fans been? Don't get me wrong, Bernie has a lot of good ideas, and 93% of time Hillary voted the same way. but who is the fighter and who is the dreamer.

Reply to Tim Kane,
What does it say about Bernie's judgment that he has built an entire campaign around grandiose promises that any second grader knows he can't keep?

Sanders is an old fox of a politician, playing dirty by smearing Clinton with unfounded accusations. He almost sounds jealous she made that much money from speeches, when he only has ripped millions from his government paycheck over decades, which by the way puts him in the top 3% in terms of income.

I never voted for her. I remember when they told all other candidates during the primary to stand down and get out of her way. It was as if the NY U.S. Senate seat was owed to her in exchange for something, maybe her agreeing to not not divorce her husband after the Lewinsky scandal or something, and the NY voter was just collateral damage.

Yiannis, Sanders didn't smear Clinton with unfounded accusations. You can't "smear" someone with the truth. And where in the world did you get your idea that he "ripped millions from his government paycheck over decades, which by the way puts him in the top 3% in terms of income."? His net worth is among the lowest in Congress at under $700,000. http://moneynation.com/bernie-sanders-net-worth/ He is scrupulously ethical and honest.

Jay, Hillary was a good senator, we all know that. Wall St was among her constituents when senator, would you have had her ignore them? To date, there is no evidence that she is "in the pocket of Wall St", instead, there is evidence that she is not. Honesty, ethics, she can stand toe to toe with anyone. If you have something real to say, do it, otherwise stop slinging mud.

If Clinton wants to convince the large proportion of Americans who do not find her trustworthy she can release the transcripts of her Wall Street speeches instead of telling us how hurt she is that she is accused of not being trustworthy.
yes, we do cowboy, and that's why we support Bernie Sanders
She has stated, and rightly so in my view, that she will release all her paid speeches when all other presidential candidates do too. Fair is fair. Same rules for all.
When Bernie and Hillary served together in the US Senate their voting records were 93% the same.

I watched the debate, and I thought Bernie Sanders was much more honest and direct with voters.  Hillary Clinton cannot answer a direct question to save her life.  She also repeatedly disrespected Sanders and the moderators with her monopolizing, paternalizing speeches that went on and on, well over the time limit.  Sanders still hasn't blamed Clinton for her role in accepting the Honduran military coup in 2009, and she needs to be called out on this.  Also, we cannot understand the immigration flows across our borders without understanding much of the migrant flow--especially from Central America--is a direct result of US foreign policy in the 1980s and '90s, and then let's throw  in the impact of NAFTA on Mexico. She represents the past policies of the US against Latin America, where he offers a much better future.  Sanders' won the debate tonight, just like he did Michigan!
Bernie got a standing ovation at the end. He had the crowd in his pocket from he time he said that he was "dangerous - to Wall Street."
NO HE DID NOT.  That was applause for the end of the debate.
" Sanders still hasn't blamed Clinton for her role in accepting the Honduran military coup in 2009,"....It was cloudy today, it must be Hillary's fault.
It's cool that he won Michigan and everything, but in terms of delegates--which is really the only category that matters--it's pretty much over.

Because delegates are apportioned and not 'winner takes all', Hillary's lead in delegate is not likely to shift. In fact, it will quite likely get larger.

She was behind by about 100 delegates after Super Tuesday in 2008. And after winning big states like CA, OH, PA, NJ, NY, etc., she was unable to overcome that deficit.

So, how will Bernie get over his more than 200 delegate deficit? There aren't enough small caucus states for him to win in that will tip the balance.

Besides, more than 4.7 million have voted for Hillary so far. For Bernie, only just over 3.0 million.

If that gap remains consistent, Hillary will win the nomination.
super delegates can switch their votes. It's not over, stop saying it.
Bernie could not get endorsements from his peers in the Seante...what does that say about him?

America has moved so much to the far right by radical right barbarians (republicans) and center right conservatives (democrats) that only electing Bernie Sanders can put the country on the correct path. It is amazing how Hillary resists on universal healthcare and higher education, more intelligent foreign policy and domestic issues, whereas all these where once American ideas that all other first world countries are using except us. America has lost almost everything except some shades of democracy, so the only hope is going out and electing Berine. Period.

"America has moved so much to the far right by radical right barbarians (republicans) and center right conservatives (democrats) that only electing Bernie Sanders can put the country on the correct path. " So you think just about everyone else has abandoned you, and electing one of the few holding similar views as yours will somehow turn all of those people back. Sounds like a paradox to me. While I understand where you are coming from, I am surprised by the logic or rather the lack of it from an engineer.

Bernie's policy of free college in public universities sounds good but has some big problems.  First, aren't the public universities controlled by the states and not the federal government? How does he propose to get the University of Texas or the University of Mississippi to go along with this? Second, there is just not enough capacity at public colleges and universities to provide free college for all in this country.
Observer, you are correct about state universities. Bernie supporters are not as smart as they think they are.

The thing that impressed me most about the debate was how it differed from the Republican debate. Unlike the Republicans, Sanders and Clinton actually debated substance -- at times -- and somehow managed to do it without calling each other names or comparing body parts.

I was listening to Rush Limbaugh today, and he was talking about a poll (which I think he sponsored) which concluded that what evangelicals wanted was not so much a particular position -- not even on abortion -- as much as they wanted a strong, take charge leader, his point being that Trump would get evangelical support as well as Cruz would. I have no idea of the existence, let alone the validity, of the referenced poll, but if Limbaugh is right, then tonight's debate should demonstrate that a significant number of evangelicals will seriously consider Clinton and Sanders if, when appropriate, the candidates talk to evangelicals -- not their self-appointed leaders -- in a serious and respectful manner.

That evangelicals prefer a 'Strong, take- charge leader' is a great way to sugar caot what recent sociological studies have found: they have a strong preference for someone with an authoritarian streak.

Sanders spoke at Liberty University last September and addressed that audience with great respect. No other democrat running for president has ever spoken at Liberty University, and Sanders delivered honesty and consistency where others fear to tread. It was not his usual stump speech - it was a remarkable attempt to establish common ground in spite of some non-negotiable differences. Anyone who thinks Sanders can't tackle gridlock should check it out. You can find the full speech on youtube.

Yes it will be a cake walk, after all there is no chance there are any skeletons in Trumps many walk in closets and the fact that he knows nothing about legislation or governing or foreign relations are irrelevant. The environment will be fantastic, the wall will be amazing and all unemployed workers will get to caddy at a Trump golf course of their choosing.
Hillary lost Michigan because she lied.  This seems to reflect her personality.  This woman cannot be trusted and she is not ethical.

Because the money for the auto industry that was taken from the bailout was done AFTER the initial vote, and she knows that; it wasn't included originally, and yet she keeps trying to say that he voted against bailing out the auto industry, and continues to say it, even after she was called out for it after the last debate; therefore, she is, at the very least, being misleading people.

1. Because the money for the auto industry that was taken from the bailout was done AFTER the initial vote, and she knows that; it wasn't included originally, and yet she keeps trying to say that he voted against bailing out the auto industry, and continues to say it, even after she was called out for it after the last debate; therefore, she is, at the very least, being misleading people.

2. Bosnian sniper fire. I have been in an active shooting situation; it's something you would never forget or be mistaken about.

I could add more that are fact, not propaganda, but I have no more time right now.

you may be right, but she has conveniently flip flopped on many many issues. The latest being Governor of Michigan. Earlier she was not calling for him to resign, suddenly on the Flint stage she says he must resign. She's an opportunist. Looks very suspicious versus Bernie's unwavering positions.

Too bad we could not hear tonight Hillary's explanation of why she supported as Secretary of the State the ousting of a democratically elected president, president Zelaya of Honduras. And regarding that "gotcha" attempt from Univision with the Cuba question well let me tell you that Cuba is probably not even on the list of problems that 99% of the Hispanic community in the USA care or are worried about. It's interesting though that Hillary was so ready to remember and comment about what was said during that video clip so many years ago, like if she almost knew that question was going to be asked during the debate.

Bernie Sanders are you or have you ever been a member of the Communist party?

Commie bashing, black listing 'reds under the bed' smear campaign Cold war rhetoric of the 1950s.

Hillary Clinton - progressive democrat candidate for president in 2016

Joe McCarthy would be proud of you.
Ramos did say his daughter works for the Clinton campaign. I would not be surprised if she was tipped off on it.

Supporting a leader who provides health care and education for the people is not a bad thing to do.  Hammas does it in Lebanon, and they win the hearts and minds of their people by providing things for the people.   We of course also need to encourage the dictators to have free elections, release politcal prisoners, and allow free press. which they can learn from us, but we can learn from them too and there is nothing wrong with copying a dictator where he gets it right.

This debate is the epitome of why so many Americans are supporting Trump. Trump is talking about the hardships actual US citizens are facing. Liberals, on the other hand, seem to be more concerned about the problems non-citizen illegals are having.

Trump has hit a nerve, obviously, but look a little closer.
Many Fortune 500 American companies have moved off shore.
Why?
Hey, you want to look like China and have companies put out nets off the top of their buildings to capture suicidal employees - vote Trump.

Trump is talking about the hardships actual US citizens are facing? Last night I heard him on my radio talking about Trump steaks, Trump wine and Trump water (none of which are actually Trump products, by the way.)

Donald Trump rarely talks about US citizens. Donald Trump mostly talks about Donald Trump.

Democrats are actually talking more about the needs of ordinary citizens than any Republican but they weaken their position by giving illegal immigrants too much sympathy and respect.  They need to tell them, "We are a nation of laws and you broke our laws. You should expect consequences."  What those consequences are can be debated but the fact of the violation should not be.

One would have to be impressed by economics as a science to be impressed by a Nobel Prize in it.  I think it's a mixture of science, ideology, and physics envy, with the last two factors more dominant than the science.

Regulation is good.

But if your regulators are not capable, either because the bankers' sophistication outmatches the regulators or because of regulatory capture, then what?

Is more regulation the answer? Or is less, but simpler and more straightforward regulation the answer (e.g. more capital against risk)?

I think the most telling part of the debate came when they showed a clip of an interview in which Sanders is praising Castro and the Cuban revolution. Most voters don't yet know that Sanders describes himself as a Socialist; but if he were to become the nominee, Republicans would make sure that every voter knows, and they would play that clip of Sanders praising Castro, over and over and over. The Republicans would destroy Sanders with that clip alone, and half of what is left of the Democrat Party will go down with him.
Then I hope they will play the complete clip, so at least it will be in context.

Dan Stewart - "Note that all criticisms from Clinton supporters are either fear'based or from the Right."...You are correct. They are fear based. The fact is that Sanders has not been vetted. The fear is the near certainty that Sanders will be crucified in a general election. That the Supreme Court will be hard right wing for years to come. That ACA and the Iran negotiations will be cancelled, and I will have to live through a President Trump or President Cruz. You should be afraid too. The fact that so many posts here have given that so little serious consideration is scary.

Dan, you are wrong. Clinton has treated him with kid gloves. Being the better politician, she recognizes the need not to give ammunition to the other side. He, on the other hand, has created red herrings, throwing raw meat to the right. He is a spoiler, and goes forth with the attitude it's him, or no one.

What are the three biggest catastrophes of 2016 America ?

1. 0.1% legalized campaign bribery corruption, which directly turns every other public policy issue into a hostage crisis

2. The psychopathic Wall Street 'vampire squid' parasite that strip mines the entire nation for personal profit and fun (this is a result of catastrophe #1)

3. The unregulated, greedy for-profit 18% of GDP healthcare extortion corporate racketeering system that delivers middling healthcare (this is also a result of catastrophe #1)

Bernie wants to cut the heads off of these three monsters which all deserve to die yesterday.

That's the right attitude.

Will Bernie be successful at it if elected President ?

Maybe - maybe not ?

But at least he's identified the dragons and communicated quite clearly and convincingly in no uncertain terms that those heads have to come off - or at least be severely shrunken - for the country to be saved from the great Robber Baron class and the Great Plutocratic Train Robbery....and he's ready to fight for it.

Hillary wants to triangulate our way out of it.

Triangulation may be an a semi-effective governing methodology, bit it's no way to win an election.

Bernie's attitude is the right one as he showed tonight:

"I am proud that the gentleman who is head of Goldman Sachs...didn't give me $225,000 for speaking fees....he said I was dangerous. And he is right, I am dangerous for Wall Street"

Anyone who's dangerous for Wall St. is a friend of the American people.

You didn't answer my questions. Why? They're not relevant?
Bernie did not get one bill passed in his Senate career but suddenly he's going to forge alliances that never existed before? Explain how this will be achieved. If a Republicans control both chambers what will Sanders offer in return? You can't get something for nothing so what does Sanders have in his arsenal to offset that?

Second, concerning ISIS Sanders says that he will build a coalition using forces from countries there. But isn't it true that many of these same countries aren't committing because they do see the US as all in to defeating ISIS? How much logistical support would he give? Special forces? Continued air strikes? Where are the specifics?

What will Sanders do about the Iranians violating the nuclear deal by testing ICMB's? What about Assad in Syria? China building man islands and blocking vital shipping lanes in the South China Sea What about China placing a missile defense system they installed?

Tax Wall Street. And then what? Where will the capital come from for drug companies to develop new drugs for Type 1 diabetes? Dementia? Heart diesease? Crohn's Disease? Sanders? You?
How will research facilities develop new surgical techniques if the money is not there from donors who don't have the money to give? Aren't many research projects funded by Wall Street ? These people who think they are owed anything are owed nothing. I worked for what I have. So should these I am entitled spoiled brats!

"Maybe - maybe not?"
Socrates, as Ms. Collins says, Hillary is more capable, more effective. But she has a terrible demeanor. She comes across as too aggressive. She ought to be more deferential to Bernie. Then voters would like her & won't be hesitant to vote for her, concluding that Bernie can't win in November. She has to change her style.

Most Democrats love Bernie. Surprisingly he is forceful & articulate. He has always been sincere, which doesn't have much market value in politics. Hillary must realize that. He is more impressive than George McGovern, or Bill Clinton. I wish he tried to run a lot earlier. Now he will be 75 before the election, which is a big impediment.
Back in the late 50s, Brooklyn College had free tuition for day students.  I attended at night, and the classes were $9 per credit.
